27 April. Youth barricaded the Nandi Hills-Chemelil road to protest surging crime in the area. The demos were spurred after two were discovered dead in a suspected bout of gangsterism.
27 April. Residents of Kagaene, Tigania West blocked a road in protest of a construction delay.
25 April. Residents of Loruk protest over police insecurity following a spate of crime and cattle rustling.

24 April. While police perused a suspect in a Miritini building, a crowd gathered outside, claiming the man was the wrong person and mentally challenged. Police tried to disperse the group by shooting into the crowd, killing one and injuring three.
24 April. A vigilante militia lynched two suspected members of a criminal gang in Busia.
21 April. Cattle thieves engage Tugen militia in a gun battle. One Tugen herder killed, 50 cows stolen.
19 April. Residents of Mwiki protest the poor state of an road.
18 April. Residents of a Mombasa neighbourhood protest forced evictions.
17 April. Boda Boda riders hold a place card-carrying demonstration governor Ann Wairguru in Kutus.

17-18 April. At least three people were shot during a confrontation between resettlement scheme dwellers and anti-riot police. The three were in a group trying to resist the settlement of the beneficiaries of the recently surveyed and subdivided 44,000-acre Mwea Settlement Scheme. The police opened fire into the crowd. The extent of the victim's injuries are not known. A second source claims 5 injured, and occurring on 18/04.
16 April. Motorists in Tharaka South blocked the Nkondi-Miomponi road to protest its poor state. The protesters blocked access to Meru.
15 April. Protest in Kisumu calling for the release of Raphael Wanjala, an MP who was arrested the previous evening. The MP was arrested after barring another MP from inspecting an area bridge.
15 April. University of Nairobi students protest the swearing-in of a newly elected student leader, calling the recent election a 'sham.'
13 April. A former district commissioner and three others are attacked and injured in Mwea over a land disagreement. One victim later died.

11 April. Two people were killed and seven others injured after armed men raided Salima village in Laisamis sub county on April 11, 2018. The attack is believe to be linked to a rivalry between two communities. The attack is believed to be related to an attack in the area under similar circumstances three days prior
11 April. Local contractors in Kathwana, Tharaka-Nithi County protest to demand unpaid salaries.
11 April. Teachers staged a protest at the Knut headquarters in Nairobi in a bid to eject Secretary General Wilson Sossio for 'acting in contravention of the law.'
11 April. A teacher at Okimaru ACK Primary School, was shot dead in Malakisi, Sirisia by unidentified perpetrators. The reason for the attack is not known.
11 April. Nyeri KMTC students held demonstrations in protest of a planned transfer of the principal.
Weapons seizure: 11 April. Police forces dismantle an al Shabaab camp in Ijara. No arrests reported, though a number of weapons were recovered.
11 April. Students of Daystar University protest to demand the removal of the Vice Chancellor over mismanagement. Police used tear gas against the protesters; no reported injuries.

11 April. Nine members of a church group are injured after unidentified assailants attack a meeting. The reason for the attack is not known, though it may be related to a new member who had recently converted from another, unnamed religion.
10 April. Residents of Nyalenda lynch a man they suspect of murder.
10 April. Scores injured when supporters of Kitui Governor Charity Ngilu (NARC) and those of Mwingi Central MP Gideon Mulyungi (WDM) clash in Mwingi town. One arrest reported.
08 April. Three members of the same family are killed in an attack based on community rivalry in or near Salima village in Laisamis sub county.
05 April. A man, upset over police performance following a fire, attacks a station in Kirigi and injures four.
04 April. Police teargassed public universities staff who were protesting at the Ministry of Education offices in Nairobi. The staff was protesting over pay. No reported injury.
03 April. Two Kilifi elders narrowly escape death in Kilifi after they were attacked over witchcraft claims.
03 April. Two are killed including a former Ukunda Ward aspirant in the 2017 General Election and two others injured when unidentified gunmen attacked Ukunda.
01 April. The home of a suspected kidnapper is destroyed by a vigilante mob in Kisii. Later, a woman was reported missing, though it is unclear if the two events are linked.

28 March. Six people were killed and two others seriously injured in a militia attack near Kenyan border with Ethiopia. Occurring in Chiroqo, Banisa Sub County, most of the victims come from Degodia clan who have been having disputes with Garre community.
28 March. Youths protest over the attempted deportation of an ODM/NRM leader in Kisumu.

28 March. Government authorities assault, drug and deport to the UAE a leading opposition figure, Miguna Miguna (ODM/NRM). Miguna locked himself in the airport washroom to avoid his flight the day before.

27 March. Police officers assault and injured a journalist covering the attempted deportation of Miguna Miguna, a prominent ODM/NRM attorney and opposition activist. The assault took place at Jomo Kenyatta International Airport.
26 March. A woman is attacked and injured in an attack over land control. The attack took place in Osure Legio village in Ndhiwa, Homa Bay County.
25 March. Students of Sagero Secondary School, 5km SW of Migori go on a 'rampage' demanding the immediate removal of Principal. The school was closed due to the unrest.
25 March. A vigilante mob lynches a woman they accused of witchcraft.
24 March. Cattle herders killed 10 in Lopurio area in Samburu North in communal violence.
23 March. Five are injured when demonstrators protesting a kidnapping and murder engage in running battles with police. A similar protest took place in Kakamega on 17 March.
Defusal: 21 March. An explosive is found in the Kaptembwa area of Nakuru. Police forces safely disposed of the device. The perpetrators are not known.
20 March. Sex workers demonstrate to promote awareness on the use of Pre-Exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) to curb HIV infections.
19 March. Teachers from Wajir region staged protests at the Teachers Service Commission headquarters in Nairobi over the state of insecurity in the region.
19 March. Students of Nyeri National Polytechnic engage in running battles with police. The protests began as students called for the students' council be reinstated.
17 March. After the body of a kidnapped girl is discovered in Kakamega, angered residents set ablaze the house of the father of the man suspected to be behind the crime.
14 March. University of Nairobi lecturers protest over salaries.
14 March. A roadside IED results in two KDF soldiers killed and an unspecified number and an unspecific number wounded. Perpetrating actor not named by the source.
13 March. Residents of Scheme estate protest over insecurity after a child had gone missing several days earlier.
12 March. Students of Turkana University College protest fees. Many of the students blocked roads surrounding the school.
08 March. Health workers in Lamu strike and protest alleged mistreatment from management on 08 March.

On 3rd July, a bomb disposal squad from the Kenya Defence Forces succesfully defused an IED (the source attributes Al Shabaab as being responsible for placing the device) in between Sangailu and Hangaro (Sangailu coded as the location, with coordinates for the precise site accurate to 5km taken from the source).
05 March. Pupils protest an attempt by 'land grabbers' to confiscate school land.
05 March. Several student protesters and journalists are arrested during a demonstration against Kenyatta National Hospital management.
Al Shabaab fighters attack Fino, Mandera. Four police and one reservist killed, two police missing.
Protests have taken place in the western town of Eldoret after a court nullified the election of Nandi Hills Member of Parliament Alfred Keter. The election was sued over 'irregularities.'
Environmental protesters gather in Uhuru Park on Thursday to protest the passage of the Standard Gauge Railway through the Nairobi National Park.
After Central Karachuonyo MCA Julius Gaya was barred by security guards from entering the Homa Bay Assembly, supporters attempt to break down a gate that was preventing his entrance.
Meru University students riot over fees, engage in running battles with police. Police opened fire, shot and killed one. The second source claims the event took place on 27/02.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) General Service Unit
notes: 28 Feb. Police repulsed an al Shabaab attack on a station in Wajir. Three suspects were arrested by a combined team of General Service Unit and AP officers. Police said the attackers fired into the camps, leading to a gunfight that lasted almost 20 minutes.
Two suspected thieves are lynched by vigilantes in Nyeri on 28/02.

Youths violently protested after they discovered a man transporting charcoal in Mwingi. Efforts by police officers to take charge of the scene aborted as they were also stoned and chased away by angry residents who accused them of abetting the charcoal trade and protecting those involved. The carrier of the charcoal was nearly lynched.
27 February. A human rights defender was shot and killed by police in Meru by police.

More than 300 boda boda riders from Murang'a County rode to Meru County (exact location not known) on Monday where they arrested a suspected motorcycle thief, lynched him and beat up policemen who tried to intervene to disperse them. The officers lobbed teargas canisters and shooting in the air. The riders smashed the police van's windows injuring two officers. Journalists were also repulsed. After the police fled, the riders stoned the suspect to death and burnt him.

More than 300 boda boda riders from Murang'a County rode to Meru County (exact location not known) on Monday where they arrested a suspected motorcycle thief, lynched him and beat up policemen who tried to intervene to disperse them. The officers lobbed teargas canisters and shooting in the air. The riders smashed the police van's windows injuring two officers. Journalists were also repulsed. After the police fled, the riders stoned the suspect to death and burnt him.

Protesters blocked the main road deflating the tyres of more than 100 vehicles in Limuru, bringing traffic to a halt for close to four hours. The protesters were demanding the arrest of Governor Charity Ngilu over the burning of a charcoal tuck in Kitui.

Police engaged in running battles with protesters who were deflating car tyres on the Naivasha-Nairobi Highway. The protesters were decrying harassment by the Kitui County officials following a ban on charcoal kilns and transportation last month.
Defusal: While on patrol between along the Hulugho-Galmagalla road, security forces spotted two al Shabaab IEDs and dismantled them.

A team of foreign investors cut short its visit to Marakwet West sub-county after they were attacked by local residents. The team was on a reconnaissance tour of Kipsaiya, the area proposed for the construction of a Sh35 billion multipurpose dam, when they were pelted with stones. The residents accused the investors to 'greed.'
A vigilante group lynched two suspected cattle thieves near Kodada village, Rachuonyo East sub county.
Police and hawkers clash over the removal of sales stalls. The running battles occurred the day fallowing the removal operations.

Operations at the governor's office in Nyahururu Town were paralysed following protests against the County Public Service Board. Residents want the board removed over claims of incompetence, nepotism and corruption.
Property destruction: 'Land grabbers' attack a farm in Chepchoina, destroy 200 houses. The attack displaced a number of people.

'One INGO male staff member needed medical attention after he was shot twice by armed perpetrators who ambushed the organization's vehicle. The staff members (five in total but only one was wounded) were in the vicinity of Darer Dima and traveling from Malkadaka to Garbatulla when they were attacked. Nothing was stolen from the passengers. While it was reported that the aid workers did not appear to be targeted specifically for their affiliation to an aid organization and that there has been an increase in insecurity in greater Isiolo county, it should also be noted that the vehicle was clearly marked.'

Youth on Tuesday pelted Mombasa Deputy Governor William Kingi's convoy with stones when he visited Likoni accompanied by MP Mishi Mboko. The protesters feared the county government wanted to destroy their business and other structures built on road reserves in the area.

A man who was killed had his eyes gouged out while a pregnant woman is shot and her body mutilated at Malkagufu area. The attack is believed to be related to clashes between Degodia and Arjuran groups since December. It is not clear who the victim/perpetrator is in this instance. The attack occurred on or before 20/02.
Residents of Mweru location in Meru County lynched a man suspected to be behind the killing of two children.

Seven suspects believed to be part of a group of militants arrested in Isiolo County last week were arrested by security officers in Mbarambate, Garbatulla. Two others were shot and killed while trying to escape.
Business in Luanda Town was disrupted on Monday when matatu crew blocked the busy Kisumu-Luanda-Busia highway to protest alleged harassment by Vihiga County enforcement officers.
A vigilante mob attacks and kills suspected rapist.
Four members of the Nyumba Kumi initiative were shot, hacked and decapitated by unidentified armed group in Saria, Cheptais sub-county. The reason for the attack is not known.

Police have foiled a 'major terrorist attack' after fighting off gunmen, killing one and arresting two others, after which they found a cache of arms including 36 grenades and five automatic rifles. Initial investigations showed the car was headed to Nairobi where the group planned to use it as a Vehicle Borne Improvised Explosive Device (VBIED).
Al Shabaab fighters attack Qarsa Primary School in Wajir. Three teachers killed, one injured. Assailants escaped.

An al Shabaab suspect was killed while two others were arrested after engaging police officers in a gun battle at their hideout in Merti, Isiolo County. Police recovered more than 1,000 bullets, 36 grenades, 18 IEDs, 5 AK-47 rifles and an assortment of other weapons.
15/02, PM Wajir: Al Shabaab attack a school killing 3 teachers.
Two Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) soldiers have been killed during a shootout between them and police officers at Sheikh Barrow in Mandera County. The exchange may have been a case of mistaken identity.
14/02, AM, Boni Forrest: Kenyan forces claim to kill three al Shabaab after being ambushed.
Al Shabaab fire several mortar rounds towards KDF base in El Ram, Mandera County. No casualties, assailants escaped.
Al Shabaab launched mortar file against a military base in El Wak over two days. Casualties reported, number not provided.
Youths held protests in Kisii Town against remarks by Embakasi East MP Babu Owino against Interior CS Fred Matiangi. The protesters threatened to disrupt a NASA rally.
Al Shabaab launched mortar file against a military base in El Wak over two days. Casualties reported, number not provided.
Residents of Witu protest on 09/02 and 11/02 against the government appointment of an area chief.
Residents of Witu protest on 09/02 and 11/02 against the government appointment of an area chief.
IED targets Kenya Police land cruiser headed to location of previous al Shabaab attack near Kutulo. No casualties & no damages.
Al Shabaab attacks a military camp at Kutulo, Wajir during the morning hours. The bodies of three belonging to the attackers were later found in the area.
A suspected thief is attacked and killed by a vigilante group.
Clashes erupt between protesters and police in Eastleigh over Qalbi Dagax Case.
Opposition NASA legislators were turned away by police when they sought to have their statements recorded over the protest swearing-in of their leader Raila Odinga as president.
Residents and family of the step mother to the leader of the outlawed National Resistance Movement Miguna Miguna, protest against her possible political deportation.
Violent protests in Awasi over two days due to the detention of opposition activist Miguna Miguna. The riots became larger on 07/02 when residents learnt that Mr Miguna had been deported to Canada.

Police in Kericho were forced to use teargas to disperse youth who had blocked the Kericho-Kisumu highway at Kericho. Chaos erupted Wednesday shortly after two vehicles arrived in Kericho with shattered windows and dented bodies following continued attacks by rioters in Awasi at the border with Kisumu County. The protests in Awasi were related to the detention of opposition activist Miguna Miguna.
Violent protests in Awasi over two days due to the detention of opposition activist Miguna Miguna. The riots became larger on 07/02 when residents learnt that Mr Miguna had been deported to Canada.

Police engage in running battles with NASA protesters. The protesters had entered Milimani Law Courts to against National Resistance Movement leader Miguna Miguna, who is being tired on grounds of treason.

Protests erupted in Migori to demand police produce lawyer Miguna Miguna in court. The youth blocked the main road linking the town to Tanzania through Isebania as they demanded to know why Mr Miguna had not been produced in court as ordered.

Riots erupted in Ahero, Kisumu County as a group of young men clashed with police after a man was shot dead during protests against lawyer Miguna Miguna's detention. The police argued the shot was in self defence. A later report asserted 5 were shot, of which three died.
Approximately 100 protest against the off-airing of 4 opposition leaning broadcast networks. Police used tear-gas to disperse the protesters.
Students of Meru University of Science and Technology on Monday engaged police in running battles at Nchiru Market and blocked roads over school fees.
Protests in Kibera for the release of Miguna Miguna.
Two inmates at Nyeri Prison, King'ong'o, were shot and injured by a senior prison warder in unclear circumstances. Prison staff claimed 'accident.'
A United States conservationist and ivory trade investigator, Esmond Bradley Martin, was found dead in his house in Nairobi under suspicious circumstances.

Kibera residents in Nairobi demanded the release of Miguna Miguna on Sunday. In solidarity, the residents thronged the streets asking the Government to immediately free the National Resistance Movement (NRM), self-proclaimed general, Miguna.
A group of youth in Mombasa, wanting Nasa leader Raila Odinga to appoint Governor Hassan Joho as his deputy, protest for his appointment.

Chaos erupted along Southern Bypass and a section of Kibera in Nairobi after rowdy youth barricaded roads, burning tyres in protest of Miguna Miguna's arrest. Traffic along the road has been disrupted and motorists advised to use alternative routes.

More than 2,000 people fled their homes on the West Pokot-Elgeyo Marakwet border after 'bandits' burned at least 70 houses.The houses were torched in a retaliatory attack. The group stormed in, injured four people and stole an unknown number of livestock.
Police at Integrity Centre, Nairobi have used teargas to disperse a section of National Super Alliance (NASA) legislators who had gone to inquire about the arrest of Ruaraka MP TJ Kajwang

Non-violent activity: The dawn attack at the residence of former Vice President Kalonzo Musyoka in Karen has been termed as an attempt to intimidate the Opposition over their strong position on electoral reforms. No injuries reported.

National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters on Tuesday took to the streets in western Kenya to celebrate Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'. The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

A section of the youth attending the National Super Alliance (NASA) swearing-in at Uhuru Park have destroyed the banner at General Post Office (GPO) roundabout along Uhuru Highway and Kenyatta Avenue. Police have since lobbed teargas to disperse the crowd that was also blocking traffic along those roads.

National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters took to the streets in western Kenya to celebrate Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'. The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.
Thousands of National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters attended on Tuesday Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'.

National Super Alliance (NASA) supporters on Tuesday took to the streets in western Kenya to celebrate Raila Odinga's swearing in as the 'people's president'. The peaceful celebrations were devoid of police presence and running battles, as has been the case whenever Opposition backers are on the streets to demonstrate.

Lamu County health workers took to the streets of Lamu Island to demonstrate against recent allegations that they were complicit in Al Shabaab activities. The doctors, clinical officers, nurses and lab technicians from various hospitals, dispensaries and health centres across Lamu also marched to Lamu County Commissioner Gilbert Kitiyo's office.

Two soldiers were killed after their truck ran over an Improvised Explosive Device at Handaro, Holugho sub-county, Garissa County. Three other soldiers who tried to jump off the vehicle were reportedly shot at close range by the suspected militia and were seriously wounded.
Residents of Marta Ward in Taveta sub-county protest against the fencing off of a water source which was stationed on private property.

Residents of Mwingi Town Tuesday barricaded the Mwingi-Garissa highway and offloaded all the charcoal from a lorry ferrying the commodity to Nairobi in a bid to fight the illegal trade which is seen as a major threat to the ecosystem in the region.

Hundreds of mostly female activists marched in Kenya's capital Nairobi on Monday to protest repeated failures to apply laws that women must hold at least a third of government seats. According to Kenya's 2010 constitution, women must have at least a third of seats in parliament and a third of appointed positions.

Property destruction: Al-Shabab militants have destroyed a Hormuud communication mast located on the Somalia border town of Elwak. Police say the militants were retaliating to earlier reports of locals communicating with Somalia security forces and the Kenya Amisom troops.

A Kenyan official says four children have been killed by an explosive device that went off in a field where they grazing livestock. Mandera Governor Ali Roba is blaming devices that Britain might have planted during its colonial occupation of Kenya for the deaths on Saturday. He asked security agents to clear the fields of any devices from before Kenya gained independence in 1963.
Youths blocked both sides of Mombasa Road at Mlolongo area on Wednesday morning to protest the delayed response of Machakos County fire fighters to put out a huge fire.

Evictions of local indigenous people led to the killing of a member of the local Sengwer community by Kenya Forest Service (KFS) rangers. Regarded as squatters by government, the Sengwer people have resisted efforts to move them from the Embobut Forest, which they see as ancestral lands.
A mob lynched and burned three men in Siaya County on Tuesday on suspicion that they were part of a notorious gang in Siaya. The men were attacked at Malunga Village in West Gem.

In Ishakani Village in Lamu East, more than 100 heavily armed insurgents took over the area and preached radical teachings to the residents. They hoisted their flag at a deserted local police station before going back to their hideouts. Sources revealed that the attackers have also been conducting daily prayers at mosques in the area at will.
Since December 2017, more than [8] people have been killed in clashes between members of the Arjuran and Degodia clans at the Eldas and Wajir North sub-counties boundary. Dates not provided.
Armed groups killed a woman and injured five police officers at Nyongoro along the Lamu-Malindi road
Youngsters gathered to protest against the arrests of three people for Saturday's events.
Kenyan officials said a civilian was killed and several policemen wounded when suspected members of the Somalia-based group al-Shabaab attacked a convoy of vehicles.
People violently demonstrated against the arrest of a local sheikh and destroyed property, especially churches. Three dead.
A woman was burnt to death while her husband was shot and injured when thugs invaded their home in Nyamira County on Friday night.

One person has been shot dead in Bonyunyu, Nyamira County as villagers protested the planned construction of a controversial dam. Police also arrested three people among them two women even as villagers said they are not ready for the project.

Uneasy calm is slowly returning to St Mary's Mission Hospital in Gilgil, Nakuru County, after days of tension and violent confrontations due to a property ownership battle. The confrontations saw a vehicle torched and operations paralysed at the institution
Suspected al-Shabab militants have destroyed a Safaricom communication mast in Kutulo, Wajir County.
Angry boda boda riders in Malindi on Saturday burnt down a Simba Coach bus after it hit and killed one of them along the Mombasa-Malindi highway

More than 800 employees on Friday protested at the Satellite section in Mai Mahiu. Ongoing construction of the Nairobi-Naivasha phase of the Standard Gauge Railway (SGR) has been suspended in the last three days as workers protest low pay and harsh working conditions.
A 32-year-old man was lynched by a mob after he killed his girlfriend following a domestic dispute in Kirindinyi Village, Voi in Taita Taveta County.

Al-Shabab has claimed responsibility for an attack on a Kenyan police station located along the common border in Mandera on 2 January. 'Reports from al-Shabab Mujahideen say that six soldiers (police) were killed in the attack with one being the commander of the police in the area, four were killed in the raid on the police camp while two other soldiers were killed in an ambush while they were rushing to back up their colleagues from El Waq town,' the website reported.

Kenya Defence Forces soldiers killed five suspected al-Shabab militants believed to have been involved in the attack on Ijara Police Station in Garissa. KDF said a vehicle that had been taken away by the militants during the attack on the Ijara station on Saturday, 30 December was destroyed after explosives it was carrying exploded during a gunfight that ensued between the soldiers and the militants.

Transport along the busy Nairobi-Naivasha was Saturday morning paralysed for more than two hours after squatters at Soko Mjinga barricaded the road protesting a move to construct a high cost cemetery within the locality.

Al Shabaab terrorists have set on fire two police camps in Ijara, in the latest attack from the Somalia-based militant group. The attackers also destroyed the main communication equipment used in the town before speeding off with a police land cruiser which is yet to be recovered. A senior police officer briefed on the matter has told Capital News beat that no casualty was reported in the attack.

Commercial sex workers in Kisii Town on Friday protested against the killing of their colleague on Wednesday. They matched though Kisii Town streets, calling for justice, wearing red T-Shirts inscribed 'Stop Violence against Commercial Sex Workers'.

Reports from Lamu Island say a deadly attack was carried out in parts of the island. The attack was a well-planned ambush targeting a vehicle carrying 'Kenyan crusaders' travelling on the road that connects Mwitu and Gamba villages in Lamu county. Al-Shabab forces, who are waging jihad in Lamu, captured the vehicle and two Kenyan infidels, who are among those settled in the Muslim land of Lamu.

Schoolchildren were playing with a device when it exploded. At least five children have been killed in an explosion in Banisa, Mandera County. Banisa Sub-County Deputy County Commissioner Mathias Chisambo said the schoolchildren were playing with a grenade they had found in a grazing field.
Since December 2017, more than [8] people have been killed in clashes between members of the Arjuran and Degodia clans at the Eldas and Wajir North sub-counties boundary. Dates not provided.

Hundreds of non-locals in Lamu town took to the streets to protest against increased attacks and killings. The protests were precipitated by the killing of a 35-year-old man who was attacked with machetes and knives at Bombay area on Lamu Island on Saturday night.
Students are protesting against what they term as poor management at the institution. Daystar University was on Friday closed due to student unrest that has rocked the institution since November.

A suspected 'terrorist' was shot dead by police in Likoni area of Mombasa. According to area police Chief Benjamin Rotich, the suspect was cornered during a raid at his house at about 3 am. The report did not specify whether the man was armed.
Angry residents lynched three suspects at Murwani village as they attempted to flee from the scene of the attack, in response to the overnight killings.
Members of the Sabaot Land Defence Force (SLDF) attacked the villages of Masaek and Kutere in Kopsiro Division in the troubled Chepyuk Settlement Scheme, leaving five people killed.

Angry residents of Bahati in Nakuru County have stoned to death two armed gangsters who had stolen household items. Police boss Edward Masibo said that the armed robbers broke into the house of a man and stole items worth more than Sh200,000.
Local villagers blockaded the UNHCR offices with burning barricades to protest against the Dadaab refugee camp.
Local villagers blockaded the UNHCR offices with burning barricades to protest against the Dadaab refugee camp.
Police lobbed teargas on Tuesday to disperse hundreds of Jubilee Party supporters outside Moi Sports Centre Kasarani where Kenyatta's oath was taking place.

Two Administration Police officers have died while three others have been injured after suspected Al-Shabaab militants ambushed an escort vehicle they were travelling in at Lango La Simba in Nyongoro, along the Lamu-Malindi road.

Police and NASA supporters clashed when police tried to block a NASA Memorial Service, held for the victims of political violence. A 7 year old boy, a pregnant woman, and a demonstrator were killed by police bullets. Several people were injured.

Teargas fired at opposition leader Raila Odinga and his supporters as they attempted to rally in Nairobi. At least two people were shot dead in clashes with police. Odinga's supporters engaged in running battles with police as they attempted to gather for a 'memorial rally' to honour nearly 60 people killed, mostly by police, in over four months of political upheaval. Two people were shot dead in Soweto (in Nairobi) as police manned Jacaranda grounds to prevent NASA's memorial service.

Kenya's security forces on Monday destroyed six Al-Shabaab training camps in an ongoing operation to flush out militants from the vast Boni forest in the coastal town of Lamu. 'Many' Al-Shabaab militants were killed and others injured during the operation.

Detonation: An explosive thrown from a moving car hit the perimeter wall of a church, causing a security scare in Mandera Town. The device, according to an eyewitness, exploded immediately after the speeding Toyota Probox turned at a corner.

A group of illegal fishermen attacked and seriously injured four police officers at Lake Naivasha on Sunday. The officers had been confiscating illegal fishing gear near Malewa bay when the group armed with crude weapons descended on them.

Three student from Isiolo Barracks Secondary School are in police custody after they allegedly attacked a soldier. The Form Four students were passing through the gate from their school after doing their national examinations when they assaulted the officer and caused disturbance.
Women in Garissa held a peaceful march to demonstrate their commitment to preventing gender based violence.

Laikipia University students at Nakuru campus on Thursday morning staged a protest after their colleague was knocked down and killed by a vehicle. The students barricaded the busy Nakuru-Nairobi highway at Mbaruk using twigs and stones disrupting traffic. Police used teargas to disperse the rowdy students who paralysed transport on the highway for 30 minutes.

Police lobbed teargas to disperse protesters at Uhuru Park on Wednesday. Reto Women Association was holding a peaceful demonstration to decry alleged police killing of over 300 livestock belonging to pastoralist communities who had invaded private ranches in Laikipia County.

'A truck contracted by a UN agency partner in Garissa county ran over an IED planted in the road. All three contracted employees sustained major injuries as a result of the attack. Although no group claimed responsibility for the attack, the area is prone to extremist activities by Al-Shabaab. The workers were delivering food commodities at the time.'

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

notes: Protesters took to the street in opposition areas in the capital and the west of the country against a court decision. A paramedic tending the injured at a demonstration in western Migori was shot dead.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.
NTV and other leading TV stations also broadcast footage of large crowds in President Uhuru Kenyatta's strongholds in Rift Valley regions celebrating the Supreme Court ruling.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.
Police have fired teargas to disperse crowds in Kisumu city to protest the Supreme Court's decision to uphold the 26 October repeat presidential poll. Protesters burned tyres on a road in the city.

Police dispersed a crowd of protesters in the Korogocho settlement in the capital, Nairobi. Youths in Kawangware engaged in running battles with anti-riot police. One protester was killed in Nairobi's Kibera slum. Hundreds penetrated a police barrier and marched along the road wielding pangas, robbing people along the way and chanting their slogans.

At least 10 houses were torched early on Monday in Mirere village, Matungu sub-county, after a boda boda rider was killed on Sunday night. Following the incident, over 50 people have been rendered homeless.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.

Supporters of President Uhuru Kenyatta took to the streets in major towns in Kiambu County to celebrate the decision by the Supreme Court to uphold his October 26 election victory. The celebrations were witnessed in the towns of Kiambu, Thika, Gatundu, Limuru, Kikuyu, Banana, Githunguri and Wangige where residents, some donning Jubilee outfits marched to the streets while waving the Kenyan flag.
On November 19, opposition supporters engaged police in running battles in many parts of Nairobi as they protested the killing of five people by Mungiki.

There were riots against insecurity in Ruaraka, the crowd burned vehicles and blockaded the road. The police fired bullets and teargas to break up the crowd. A local MP who was caught up in the riots was injured by a police bullet.

On November 19, eleven people were allegedly killed in Baba Dogo, Nairobi. Local residents blamed the killing of at least five people on Mungiki. Raila Odinga accused the government of orchestrating the attacks.
Clashes erupted in Nairobi's Mathare slum on Sunday after four bodies were found in the street, with outrage spreading to Kibera.
A NASA supporter was killed in Kibera.

assoc_actor_2: Luo Ethnic Group (Kenya); NASA: National Super Alliance
notes: 5 people in Ruaraka were shot dead by unidentified attackers during the night. Odinga says that they were targeted because they were Luos and NASA supporters.
Unidentified attackers shot at a bus that was travelling from Merti to Isiolo, killing 8 passengers.

Students at the Athi River campus of Daystar University held a silent protest against the administration. The protest degenerated into violent demonstrations, which were broken up by the police. The university has closed both the Athi River campus and the Nairobi campus in response.

NASA supporters waiting at the airport for the return of Odinga clashed with the police. The police fired teargas to disperse the crowd and the demonstrators threw rocks. The police tried to block Odinga's convoy from travelling into Nairobi.

At least five people were killed Friday in confrontations between Kenyan police and supporters of opposition leader Raila Odinga as tensions over the disputed presidential election continued. Rioters are deemed responsible of many acts of violence, inculding sexual violence and property desruption. Eyewitnesses said police shot them. 'There were 15 bodies at the City mortuary and three at Chiromo mortuary when we visited. These people were shot by the gun and cartridges collected,' claimed Raila

Kenyatta University has been closed indefinitely following a night of riots by students. There are reports that a huge fire broke out in one of the buildings in the institution.The University's Vice Chancellor Prof Paul Wainaina announced on Friday morning that the decision was prompted by the ongoing lecturers' strike that had ' heightened agitation among students'.

Embakasi East MP Babu Owino, his Rauaraka counterpart TJ Kajwang and Starehe politician Steve Mbogo were arrested Thursday as Opposition leaders engaged police in a cat-and-mouse game. The leaders were apprehended on Ngong' Road as they attempted to enter Kibra's Kamkunji ground where NASA had scheduled a rally that had been banned by the police.

Property destruction: A church at the centre of a land tussle was destroyed on 15 November at Jogoo area in Kisii Town. Church officials said hired goons descended on Millennium SDA Church and vandalised it.

Three police officers were killed on Tuesday. A team of police officers were headed back to a settlement called Lomelo from Kapedo where they delivered food rations to police camps when bandits sprayed their vehicle with bullets, killing the officers. A group of officers sent for reinforcement and rescue their colleagues were also caught up in the ambush, which left 10 with injuries and one missing.

The hearing of a petition challenging the election of Homa Bay Governor Cyprian Awiti was adjourned for more than 30 minutes after supporters of two opposing groups clashed. Governor Awiti's supporters of and those of former Kasipul MP Oyugi Magwanga fought outside the Homa Bay High Court Tuesday morning.

At least eleven houses have been razed at Esoit in Trans Mara as renewed fighting between Kipsigis and Maasai communities erupted. No fatalities following the incident as residents of Bogoria Village had temporarily abandoned their homes following prolonged insecurity.
Students in Rachuonyo rioted when their teachers prevented them from cheating in the exams. The police intervened to break up the riots.
2 people were killed by police reservists in Basargeisa, in Bura.

Three women in Kitui were allegedly tortured by police on claims of insulting a local church leader. Mrs Hellen Kyalo, Ms Janet Mwikali and Mrs Kathini Mwema from Syongila Village in Kitui Central on Friday said the officers inflicted serious injuries on their behind, thighs and legs.
A woman who stabbed her boyfriend to death after a dispute over a phone was lynched by a mob in Murang'a Thursday morning.
University dons tried to hold a peaceful demonstration in Nairobi, but were threatened by the police, who confiscated their megaphones and blocked the road so that the march could not pass.

Beneficiaries of government-allocated land clashed with squatters in Taveta. Eye witnesses report that 2 people were killed by bows and arrows in the clashes, although the authorities deny these deaths.
Residents of Narok protested against the rising insecurity.

Transport in Mandera County has been paralysed after operators suspended bus services in the county for three days after al-Shabab attacked two police vehicles on Monday evening. Al-Shabab militants ambushed and burnt down two police land cruisers in an attack in Daba City, Mandera County on Monday. The two vehicles carrying police officers were escorting a bus to Mandera when they were hit by rocket-propelled grenades. 12 killed, several wounded.

The KDF intercepted an Al Shabaab group of militants who was heavily armed and planning to carry out attacks in Lamu West on Thursday. An operation (Linda Boni) was called to capture the militants who escaped during the gun battle into the Boni forest. During the incident, six AK-47 assault rifles, 321 bullets, three grenades and explosives were recovered.

Police were patrolling the private ranches in Ol Moran and Ratia and were attacked by the pastoralists when they tried to evict them. There was an exchange of fire between the officers and the pastoralists who were all armed. The latter destroyed a vehicle, after which the police countered with fire in a 2-hour long battle.
Al Shabaab militants attacked a land cruiser in Arabia. They stole the land cruiser and shot at the passengers. 2 passengers were injured.
Al Shabaab militants hijacked a car and abducted a driver between Fino and Sheikh Barrow. He is alive, but being held in Somalia.

2 journalists were assaulted by youth during a NASA Parliamentary Group meeting at the Wiper headquarters in Nairobi. The journalist, who had already been verbally assaulted before the attack, were singled out due to working for Citizen, NTV, KBC and therefore were seen as being biased and leaning towards the re-election of the President Uhuru Kenyatta. Mr. Gachuri was forcedully evicted while Mrs. Gatwiri was slapped in the face.

Transport along Kericho-Kisumu Highway on Tuesday was disrupted after matatu owners blocked the road near Parkmatt supermarket protesting vandalism of their two vehicles. Anti-riot police fired teargas to disperse the protesters. Some vehicle passengers were injured in the process. The vehicles were allegedly vandalised near Chemelil trading center in Kisumu County by NASA supporters who were protesting the announcement of Uhuru Kenyatta as the winner of repeat presidential election.
Violence broke out in Kibera when the winner of the election run-off was declared. NASA supporters rioted and set tires alight. The police tried to break up the protests.
Police dispersed Jubilee supporters in Mumias.

In Kisumu, angry youth held demonstrations in Kondele, the main bus station and Nairobi Road complaining about the 866 votes said to have been cast in Kisumu. They lit bonfires, blocked roads and, in some cases, extorted money from motorists.

In Nairobi, several groups of supporters marched through the city's main streets singing and chanting to celebrate the win of newly-confirmed President Kenyatta. The same happened in other locations. In Narok, however, two men from different communities clashed, leaving 5 people injured.
In the slums of Kibra, in Nyamira, youth lit bonfires to protest against the election of Kenyatta.
A Land Cruiser carrying five passengers was attacked by Al Shabaab militants at Arabia area. The driver was released and two passengers suffered gunshot wounds but they were in stable condition.

A group of young people tried to prevent Cabinet Secretary Matiangi from leaving the Gatina Primary School. The cabinet secretary had moved to address the crowd when people started chanting 'Matiang'i must go!'. Police used tear gas to disperse the agitated crowd that had started pelting stones at CS Matiang'i's motorcade, and then the school. Pupils who attempted to leave the school's premises got caught up in clashes, some being rendered unconscious while others gasped for air.

The altercation between the police and protesters at the Majengo bus stage began when a car belonging to a local businessman was allegedly found with marked presidential election ballot papers. One person was shot and at least 11 others were injured. Among those beaten up was a police in civilian uniform who ran to the scene.
Kenyan police have used tear gas to disperse opposition supporters who threw stones after a government official visited a school in Kawangware.

Movement of forces: on 29 October, armed men from Waithaka and Ndonyo area raided Kabiria. Young men were armed with pangas and threatened to conduct a door-to-door search to flush out Luos and Luhyas, who they said were living on their land. No actual violence reported.
One man was found dead in a sugar cane plantation one day after ethnic tensions between the Luo and Kalenjin communities got into an ethnic clash. The body had been hacked with a panga.
Non-violent activity: Villagers from the Luo and Kalenjin communities armed themselves against each other on 28 October in Kisumu County.
Kenyan police have used tear gas in an attempt to disperse crowds of opposition supporters in the Nairobi slum of Kawangware.
Police gunned down three men suspected of having killed the two police officers. They also recovered the stolen weapons and the AK-47s. The fighting lasted for 5 hours.
Rioters demonstrated in the town of Majengo. They were incited to attack a car which was said to have ballot papers, but after damaging it, it was not confirmed.
3 police officers mistaken for protesters were beaten on Saturday afternoon by other police forces in Majengo Town during ongoing demonstrations.

Non-violent activity: In Chakol estate in Busia, police threw teargas cannisters into houses to flush out the inhabitants. They claimed to be searching for the youth who had disrupted the voting the previous day. No reported injuries.
2 Kenyan police officers are killed during an ambush in Nairobi. The attackers were armed with AK47s and they stole the officers weapons after killing them with shots from the back.

As a revenge to the previous event, the Kikuyu joined forces and attacked the Luo. The ethnic tensions and violence led to one severely injured person. Residents claims three were killed and dozens, including three school children, were injured.

Rioters started throwing stones at the police in the morning, during the demonstrations against the elections to be held the next day. The police responded with teargas and water cannons. The rioters were mostly from the Luo ethnic group and they took the opportunity to loot several stores, attack residents and to burn a store owned by an ethnic Kikuyu. One woman was raped.
Angry protesters took to the streets, blocking roads to protest the decision to redo the elections on Saturday in certain counties. Rioters got into clashes with the police.
A 17-year old is shot in the chest and injured during violent demonstrations in Sindo town.
In Migori the police stormed residential estates, where they fired teargas into homes, beat people, and raped women. 1 man was killed when he was shot in the head.
Angry protesters took to the streets, blocking roads to protest the decision to redo the elections on Saturday in certain counties.

The police opened fire on protesters who were demonstrating against the decision to hold elections again on Saturday and killed two of them in Bungoma. The demonstrators blocked the road and lit fires.

A man was shot dead while two others suffered gunshot wounds last Friday when they attempted to torch Mr Rege's home in Pala Village in Karachuonyo Constituency. Mr Rege confided to journalists that he suspected the MCAs were behind the plans to torch his home over allegations that there were ballot papers in his home marked in favour of President Uhuru Kenyatta.

Police raided houses of civilians in Kisumu, beating civilians and injuring dozens. Live bullets were used on some civilians, including a 14 year old boy. Of the 29 people injured, 26 had suffered gun shots.
Protesters took to the streets again to show their opposition to holding elections on Saturday. Outside Kisumu's morgue, 30 women stood weeping with signs saying 'Stop killing our sons'.
Youth attacked election officials at Bogwo polling station in Muhoroni. They also attacked and beat voters.

assoc_actor_2: IEBC: Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission
notes: Angry demonstrators in Kavwea, Masinga, ambushed an election official. No reports of injury.
Angry villagers who saw that a teacher had marked ballot papers gathered to set fire to his house. The civilian had already sought refuge.

Violent demonstrations break out in Kibera during the elections. Residents burned tires and blocked roads as part of their manifestation in support of Odinga. They also chained the gates of the Olympic Primary School to prevent voters from casting votes but the police managed to disperse them. Riot police fired teargas to disperse the crowds. Five people shot and injured.

Riots break out in Kisumu, with demonstrators starting fires, erecting barricades and clashing with police. Three people are killed during the clashes. A police officer sustained injuries on the knee after their vehicle was attacked by rowdy youths, who had barricaded a road in Kisumu.
A Returning Officer was attacked by demonstrators in Migori town on his way to the polling centre. He sustained slight injuries and lost a number of his personal items.
Opposition supporters in Turkana county burned election materials to protest the election run-off.

assoc_actor_1: IEBC: Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (Kenya)
notes: Non-violent activity: The IEBC announces that the voting for the presidential elections in Homa Bay, Kisumu, Migori, Siaya will be postponed to the 28th. The re-run was later cancelled with a new date to be announced.
In Rangwe market, a police officer, who was escorting ballot boxes was injured after he was hit by a stone thrown by protesting youths.

In Kondele, one of Kisumu's slums, youth protest against the elections by barricating roads with huge stones, preventing police from approaching. Police later used water canons to disperse the protesters.
A student is killed during protests in Kombewa
Residents kept off polling stations, choosing instead to protest an attack on Kisima Primary School polling station by a senior administration officer last Wednesday.
In Mombassa, demonstrators lit tyres and timbers along the main highway.
Opposition supporters barricaded the roads in Busia with burning tires. The police fired live ammunition to disperse the crowds. At least 5 people were injured.
In Dagoretti at Stage 56, rioters barricaded roads and lit bonfires. Some houses were torched near Muslim area but the rioters were later dispersed.

Youths at Oyugis town youths barricaded Kisumu-Oyugis-Kisii road with stones and lit bonfires. Police dispersed them and cleared the road but in the process, one police officer was hit with a stone and lost his front tooth while another officer was stabbed with a knife. One suspect was arrested, and a knife recovered. The windscreen of a police vehicle was also shattered.

Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators. Police and independent reports confirm 1 killed in Homa Bay and 1 seriously injured after a mob attacked a police facility.
Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators.
Within Murumba market, youths attacked an army truck that was ferrying goods from the Hakati Army Camp. The army officers fired in the air dispersing the youths.

A group of about 200 rowdy youths from neighbouring Siaya County attacked a polling station by throwing stones. In the process, one ballot box containing ballot papers was destroyed. Police moved in quickly and restored order.

actor2: Police Forces of Kenya (2013-) Prison Guards
notes: A prison warder was injured in North Rachuonyo North after he was hit by a stone as he cleared a barricaded road.
In St. Marys Bangladesh, rowdy youths blocked the entrance to the polling centre forcing the IEBC officials to suspend the exercise while arrangements were made to manage the situation.
Two people shot dead in Baba Dogo, no mention of violence by the protesters.

Rioters firebomb a church in Mathare and barricade roads leading to poll stations with rocks. After anti-riot police was deployed, the situation was controlled. The director of the hospital of Drugnet told the AFP that there was 1 killed though.
Police arrest 35 protesters who were barricading roads and disturbing the voting polls in Kakamega.
Young people pretending to be voters disturb the voting polls in Narok.

In North Karachuonyo, youths were repulsed after attempting to enter the home of former MP James Rege. Police say there were no injuries but reports indicate a man was shot and two others injured during the incident. One of them died of his wounds.
Rioters/youth clash with police in Kakamega town. During the riots, a police officer mistakenly shot a National Youth Service officer in Kakamega.

In Bungoma County, violent riots erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers. During one of these riots, a man was shot dead in a tussle with a police officer. Inspector General of Police Joseph Boinnet said the man attempted to snatch a gun from the police man. Fatality assigned to this event.

In Bungoma County, violent riots erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers. During one of these riots, a man was shot dead in a tussle with a police officer. Inspector General of Police Joseph Boinnet said the man attempted to snatch a gun from the police man.

In Bungoma County, violent riots erupted in Kimilili, Chwele and Webuye leading to confrontations with police officers. During one of these riots, a man was shot dead in a tussle with a police officer. Inspector General of Police Joseph Boinnet said the man attempted to snatch a gun from the police man.
Youths use bees to keep voters away from Matsakha polling station and are eventually dispersed by police.

At Mugai Primary School, an assistant chief was chased away by angry locals who accused him of dishing handouts to coerce people to vote. Locals said the officer was giving people perceived to be Jubilee supporters Sh50 and directing them to the polling station to cast their ballots.
A crowd sets tyres on fire to protest the presidential election vote.

In Busia, a group of boda boda drivers stormed a polling station and burnt ballot boxes, forms 32A, 33, 34A, 41, supervisor validation forms, ballot papers, IEBC stamps, badges and reflector jackets, and stole two gas lanterns and cylinders.
One man was stabbed in the neck in Likoni, Mombasa. It is not yet certain whether he was attacked on the way to vote.

Clashes break out in four western opposition strongholds, leading to shots and battles between police and demonstrators. Residents barricaded roads, lit bonfires and paralised streets to prevent voters from casting their votes.

Two people were shot dead during anti-election protests in Mavoko, Machakos county on Thursday. A 13-year-old was shot on his way to a kiosk in Sofia Slum, while a man was shot in Makadara Shopping centre. Several other people were injured in the violent confrontation between anti-riot police and protesters.
Police shot one person during protests in Siaya. They used live bullets, teargas and batons.

Police shot two people during protests in Migori. They used live bullets, teargas and batons. Youths barricaded roads with stones, electricity polls and bonfires to prevent IEBC [Independent Boundaries and Electoral Commission] from delivering voting materials in the region.
Road leading to Olympic primary school in Kibera barricaded. Anti riot police dispersed the crowd.
Armed militants (bandits) attacked a community in Laikumuku, in Tigania East. They stole 100 cattle and killed 2 people.
Police shot two people during protests in Kisumu. They used live bullets, teargas and batons: More than 20 people sustained gunshot wounds. Rioters erected barricades and lit fires
NASA activists protest outside IEBC offices
A group of women protested for a peaceful election in Langata. The protest was peaceful.

A crowd of rowdy youth clashed with police forces when attempting to break into the Migori Teachers Training College to remove election material. The hundreds of rioters were repelled by police, who shot fires into the air. The rioters blocked the highway between Kenya and Tanzania using metal containers and boulders
Two days before the presidential elections, protesters demonstrate in Nairobi. Kenyan police used teargas and shot fires in the air to disperse the crowd.
A group called Kisii County IDPs held peaceful demonstrations in the streets of Kisii calling on residents not to participate in unlawful activities before the elections.
Movement of forces: The government decides to deploy 130,000 police officers to the locations of Homa Bay Migori, Siaya, Kisumu and Migori to protect voters.

Non-violent activity: Police raid the house of former Kakamega Senator Boni Khalwale in search for materials that can be used to disrupt the Thursday election. The police claims that Mr. Khalwale was storing tyres to provide to mobilised youth, which would use them to light pyres.
A group of armed men killed 2 people in the Laikumukumu area, Tigania East District, and stole over 1000 cattle.
At least three people were injured by the police in Kisumu when protesting against the electoral commission.

The bodyguard of the Deputy Chief Justice Philomena Mwilu was shot in the shoulder while buying flowers by an armed man/group (unknown). This adds to the tension felt before the presidential election that will take place this week. Because of this, the Deputy Chief did not attend the meeting of the next day where the postponement of the presidentials elections was to take place.
Confrontation between police in Migori and NASA supporters started on Tuesday night and extended to the 25th, with businesses being closed and roads blocked. Scores injured.
There were demonstrations in Ukunda to protest police brutality.
Four Al-Shabaab members were killed by the KDF in Mararani after the soldiers raided the camp on Monday, forcing the other militants to abandon it.
Rioters who tried to disrupt a NASA rally in Keroka were beaten and chased away by NASA supporters.
The police went from house to house beating people in Ukunda.
A catholic priest was assassinated near Chiga Market, in Muhoroni.
A police operation left the son of a business owner shot dead in Nairobi. The police officers had an armoured car and the reasons for the shooting are not yet clear.

One person was on Sunday [22 October] injured during running battle between police and residents of Lucky Summer area in Nairobi. The residents were protesting the presence of suspected [proscribed] Mungiki sect members who held a meeting in the area since morning.

Police forces attacked supporters of the opposition that went to the Lucky Summer neighbourhood to check on a ritual of beheading of a sheep that was taking place (suspectedly by the Mungiki sect). The police shot at the civilians. The police confirmed that it shot a man and that the group performing the ritual had sought protection.
Nairobi's Eastleigh hold protest against Mogadishu bombing.
Five people were injured when suspected al-Shabab militants sprayed their vehicle with bullets between Bodhei and Ijara, on the border of Lamu and Garissa counties.
Five people are nursing multiple gunshot wounds after their vehicle was shot at by suspected al Shabaab militants
A teacher was beaten when a mob tried to stop an IEBC training in Homa Bay.

Kenyan police fired rifles and tear gas in Nairobi's Freedom Park on 19 October to disperse demonstrators preparing to protest police killings of opposition supporters ahead of a fresh presidential election. Injuries reported.

Protesters stormed the Huduma Centre in Kisumu city threw chairs and destroyed tents where a training camp was being set up for officials to prepare for this month's presidential election. The youths also roughed up a woman the commission had contracted to provide the tents and chairs.
Angry youths disrupted a training for electoral officials at Chango in Vihiga on 18 October.

A mob on 17 October disrupted planned training sessions for electoral officials in Nyanza, Migori. Protesting NASA supporters stormed Simba Hotel, where IEBC officials had gathered for training. Police dispersed them.
Jubilee supporters barricaded the roads in Limuru. The police did not intervene.

A mob on 17 October disrupted planned training sessions for electoral officials in three stations in Kisumu, Migori and Homa Bay counties. In Kisumu, police intervened at the Awasi Multicultural Christian Centre. Police arrest 10 of them.

A contingent of police officers were sent to Kabunde Social Hall where training for the poll officials for Homa Bay Town Constituency was taking place. Police kept at bay angry youths who threatened to attack the officials, calling them traitors.

A mob on 17 October disrupted planned training sessions for electoral officials in three stations in Kisumu, Migori and Homa Bay counties. In Homa Bay, security officers responded to rescue a group of IEBC officers gathered at Sikri School in Kasipul, after youth attacked them.

Hundreds of pro-ODM youth holding anti-IEBC protests in Kisii County on 17 October were forced to run for safety after anti-riot police lobbed tear gas canisters to disperse them. The youth were protesting the harassment of Woman Representative Janet Ong'era.
In Bondo, more than 250 people who had convened at Sironyo Academy on the outskirts of the town were roughed up by angry youth, forcing them to run for their lives. No injuries reported.
On 17 October, mobs disrupted electoral training sessions in parts of Kakamega County.

In Siaya, training was suspended in four constituencies after rowdy youth attacked the stations where the officers were undergoing their first day of coaching. They included Gem, Bondo, Ugunja and Rarieda.

In Siaya, training was suspended in four constituencies after rowdy youth attacked the stations where the officers were undergoing their first day of coaching. They included Gem, Bondo, Ugunja and Rarieda.

In Siaya, training was suspended in four constituencies after rowdy youth attacked the stations where the officers were undergoing their first day of coaching. They included Gem, Bondo, Ugunja and Rarieda.

Jubilee and Nasa supporters clashed in Laare, Meru County. Youths chanting Jubilee slogans lit bonfires. Their Nasa rivals attempted to push them out, leading to a rock-pelting match. Police officers used teargas to disperse the increasing number of pro-Jubilee youths.
NASA protesters engage police. Live bullets allegedly used. No reports of protester violence or injuries.

On 16 October, three people were injured in clashes between the Luo and the Kuria communities living in Karamu village in Migori County, located at the border of Suna West and Kuria West constituencies. One motorcycle was burnt by armed youths.
On 16 October in Migori, shops, offices and hotels were closed as Nasa demonstrators took to the streets. Police watched them from a distance and did not interfere with the demos.
Protesters clashed with the police in Kisumu's Kondele area on 16 October. A form four student was killed by gunshot in the clashes.
In Isiolo Town, Nasa supporters marched peacefully and converged outside Isiolo North Constituency IEBC offices calling for electoral reforms. The protest was led by Ms Nasibo Sora Abdirahaman.
On 16 October in Kakamega, former Senator Boni Khalwale and Lurambi MP Titus Khamala led a group of opposition supporters in anti-IEBC protests.
On 16 October in Siaya, business premises were closed as hundreds of residents demonstrated in streets. Protesters marched to IEBC offices to present their petition.

On 16 October in Homa Bay, businesses remained closed as protesters blocked main roads in the town, paralysing, transport and other operations. Police watched from a distance as protesters took to the streets.
A two-year was shot in the neck whilst playing in Nyamasaria, Kisumu County on 16 October. It is thought the bullet came from police who were engaging protesters in Lower Manyatta.

On 16 October, several Nasa leaders led by Siaya Senator James Orengo and former Machakos Senator Johnstone Muthama led their supporters into the Nairobi CBD amid running battles with police officers who used teargas to disperse them.
In Mombasa, police dispersed NASA demonstrators who were assembling with an aim of storming the CBD. Police arrested a few protesters, and several others were injured in the process.
On 16 October in Vihiga [western Kenya], residents stormed streets carrying twigs and placards, demanding IEBC reforms. They called for resignation of IEBC Chief Executive Officer Ezra Chiloba.

Movement of forces: The government's military operation in Boni Forest meant to flash out suspected al-Shabab militants is set to be extended for an unspecified period in Lamu, Garissa and Tana River counties.
Anti-IEBC protest along Moi avenue.
On 14 October, six people were killed in an attack by suspected South Sudanese raiders on a boarding school in Lokichogio.
On 14 October, a student suspected of joining an armed raid that killied six at a school in Kenya was stoned to death by angry locals.
A student suspected of joining in an armed raid that killed six at a school in Kenya's far north Saturday was stoned to death by angry locals and his body burned.

On 13 October, a 75 year old woman was shot on the right shoulder by the police as they dispersed a crowd of NASA supporter in Migori. The police say they opened fire after protesters destroyed their vehicle. Two more people were wounded by gunshots.

On 13 October, three people were shot dead when people fired live shots to disperse NASA protesters. The police shot after the protesters tried to break into the police station. The Siaya Senator claimed the police shot dead the three unarmed men at close range completely without justification.

On 13 October, 20 people were admitted to hospital during running battles between NASA protesters and the police in Kisumu. Four people had gunshot wounds including one man in a critical condition who had been shot in the neck.
On 13 October, several nursery school children were hospitalised after police fired tear gas into the Mt Carmel Academy in the Nyalenda slum.
On 13 October, police shot at protesters who had coverged to march in Homa Bay.
On 13 October, NASA supporters held a peaceful demonstration in Kakamega.
On 13 October, police shot at protesters who had coverged to march in Siaya.
On 13 October, police dispersed a group of NASA supporters who had converged to protest in Mombasa. There were reports of looting and robbery during the protests.
On 13 October, police used teargas to disperse students who barricaded roads to protest the death of a student killed by a car. They demanded justice and speed bumps.
NASA rioters in Kondele throw stones at police stations resulting in injuries.
Police lob teargas canisters against election protesters along Moi avenue on 13/10.
There were protests against the IEBC in Kisii.

Demonstrations started peacefully but turned chaotic in Homa Bay town. The rioters snatched a firearm from a police officer and threw it in a shed which they set ablaze. The mobs also threw stones at Homa Bay police station.
Demonstrators clash with police in Siaya, the clash results in gunshot wounds.
On 11 October, Kisumu Governor joined NASA anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kisumu. NASA supporters engaged in running battles with police.
On 11 October, one person was injured as police fired tear gas at more than 1000 NASA supporters marching through Nairobi. Reports indicate demonstrators damaged cars.
5 Al Shabaab militants were killed by Kenyan military during an operation in Boni Forest.
On 10 October, gunmen killed two female employees of a university in Ukunda, in a suspected extremist attack.
On 10 October, more than 10 police officers exchanged fire with suspected al-Shabab militants after nearly hitting an IED at Mambore-Mkokoni area .
In Migori, NASA demonstrators throw stones at police.
On 09 October, police used tear gas to disperse NASA protesters in Kisumu. The police also injured journalists.
On 09 October, NASA held anti-IEBC demonstrations in Homa Bay. Businesses were shut as protesters blocked roads, lit fires and marched on the streets.
On 09 October, NASA held anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kakamega.
On 09 October, a small group of NASA supporters protest in Mombasa.
On 09 October, three people were wounded during NASA demonstrations in Nairobi. A man in a car shot one person and injured tow other protesters before driving away.
In Lamu, hundreds of protesters at the Milano area in Lamu town marched to the IEBC offices declaring 'Chiloba must go'
The Mt Kenya University Senate has indefinitely shut down its Thika campus following student unrest. The learners engaged police officers in running clashes for the better part of Monday morning.
On 09 October, police used tear gas to disperse NASA protesters in Machakos.
NASA protesters light fires in Makindu and are dispersed by police.
On 09 October, five militants were killed by the Kenyan Defence Force during a raid in Boni Forest. Others escaped with injuries.
Police disperse anti-IEBC protests in Saiya. No report of violence from demonstrators.
In Vihiga, MPs Alfred Agoi (Sabatia) and Ernest Kagesi (Vihiga) led protests. They asked voters not to take part in the October 26 poll if reforms demanded by Nasa are not effected
More than 200 anti-IEBC demonstrators converged at a petrol station on the turn-off to Voi town and marched peacefully to the Scripture Mission Centre
Five Kisumu journalists were harassed, beaten and injured by police while covering the anti-IEBC demos Monday.
Students at Moi university in Eldoret protested after a student is raped by a security guard.
On 07 October, Kenyan conservationists participated in the Global March for elephants, rhinos and lions to raise awareness on threats facing the iconic wildlife species.
On 06 October, Police in Kisumu fired tear gas at crowds of opposition supporters who tried to storm the IEBC local offices ahead of a tense presidential election re-run.
On 06 October, Police in Nairobi fired tear gas at crowds of opposition supporters marching against the IEBC ahead of a tense presidential election re-run.
On 06 October, Tumaini supermarket in Kisumu was broken into and goods stolen by anti-IEBC demonstrations endorsed by NASA.
On 06 October, one person suffered gunshots wounds as police and anti-IEBC demonstrators clashed in Homa Bay town.
On 06 October, five people were arrested after a group of youths attempted to barricade a road and light bonfires during anti-IEBC protests.
Destruction of property: Shops at Gorofani are set alight. Perpatrators not known.
In Busia, rowdy Nasa supporters lobbed tear gas at the police sparking running battles.
In Mombasa, Nasa supporters held their anti-IEBC demos peacefully.

Police officer keeps guard at the gate of Kiambu Institute of Science and Technology (KIST) following violent unrest from the students. The students were demonstrating against the alleged grabbing of the institute's land, high school fees and congestion in the students hotel.

Students at the University of Nairobi protest for two days after the arrest of a former student body president, now a parliamentarian for the opposition, was arrested. His detention led students to block roads at the university campuses and clash with riot police.
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kajiado
On 02 October, anti-riot police used teargas on anti-IEBC protesters who were hurling stones at police in Nairobi and Kisumu

There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kakamega. The police blockaded the local senator in his house to prevent him joining the demonstrations. There were running battles between demonstrators and police.
On 02 October, One person died in Siaya County of Western Kenya after collapsing in a protest against the Independent Electoral and Boundaries Commission (IEBC) in the opposition stronghold.
On 02 October, anti-riot police used teargas on anti-IEBC protesters who were hurling stones at police in Nairobi and Kisumu (Kondele)
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Migori. The rioters burned down the market.
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kilifi

Students at the University of Nairobi protest for two days after the arrest of a former student body president, now a parliamentarian for the opposition, was arrested. His detention led students to block roads at the university campuses and clash with riot police.
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Kisii
Peaceful protest by NASA supporters in Mombasa
On October 2, police reportedly used tear gas in a nursery in Nyalenda, injuring at least three children.
Anti-IEBC protests in Kitui
In Homa Bay, Nasa supporters lit bonfires as they demanded the removal of IEBC CEO Ezra Chiloba and other officials accused of bungling August 8 polls.
There were anti-IEBC demonstrations in Bungoma
Anti-IEBC protests in Garissa
Police use teargas to disperse Egerton University students in Nakuru town. The students were violently protesting new examinations fees on September 29, 2017.
Motorbike taxis blockaded a road in Nairobi to protest the killing of a fellow taxi driver.

On 28 September, University of Nairobi students protested the arrest of Embakasi East MP Babu Owino. 27 students and staff at the University of Nairobi were reportedly injured when police used tear gas, beat them with wooden clubs, robbed them and threatened them with sexual violence.
A 65-year-old man was lynched by angry villagers in Kochia, Rangwe sub-county on Thursday afternoon for allegedly being a witch.
Students at Marakwet Boys School rioted and set fire to their dormitories.
Babu Owino's supporters protested outside the Milimani court, demanding his release after a second night in cell over apparent insults to the President
Migori county MCA allied to the opposition led county residents in peaceful demonstrations for free and fair elections.
NASA supporters protested at the IEBC offices in Mombasa.
2 people were killed and 1 person was injured in an attack on Ol Ari Nyiro Nature Conservancy.

On 26 September, NASA supporters in Kisumu marched to the IEBC to demand the resignation of the Commission's top officials. Dozens of heavily armed police officers stood and watched in the town's sweltering heat as protesters marched through the streets.
On 26 September, NASA supporters clashed with police outside the IEBC, while protesting the reshuffling of IEBC officials. Police officers used tear gas canisters to disperse them.
Supporters of Embakasi East MP Babu Owino have blocked a number of roads in Embakasi protesting his arrest. His followers have used boulders and wigs to block the roads inconveniencing motorists.

President Uhuru Kenyatta's supporters hold anti-opposition demonstrations in Murang'a town. President Uhuru Kenyatta said the government will not allow the IEBC officials to be removed from office unconstitutionally.
Students of a school in Makueni county marched to the sub-county headquarters in Kibwezi town on Monday in protest against their deputy principal.
On Monday, Jubilee supporters protest again against the remarks by Embakasi East MMP Babu Owino against the president. The rioters burnt tyres in Kiambu.
Eight men were found dead in Trans Mara district after dispute over land between the Maasai and Kipsigis.
A Maasai businessman was shot dead and a young boy was wounded in an incident in Esoit, in Trans Mara. Maasai villagers believe that he was killed by Kipsigi militia.
